column3: Pension Plan Deferred Outflow of Resources [Abstract]
column10: Information about pension plan deferred inflow of resources.

column3: Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments
column10: A consumption of pension related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual pension plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132b

column3: Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Changes in Assumptions
column10: A consumption of pension related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post?employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132a(2)

column3: Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience
column10: A consumption of pension related net assets deferred due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132a(1)

column3: Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pensions, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions
column10: A consumption of net assets applicable to changes in the employers proportion and differences between (a) the amounts paid by the employer for pensions as the benefits came due and (b) the employers proportionate share of the total of certain amounts paid by the employer and nonemployer contributing entities for pensions as the benefits came due.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 154

column3: Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date
column10: A consumption of pension related net assets due to contributions to the pension plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 133

column3: Pension Plan Deferred Inflow of Resources [Abstract]
column10: Information about pension plan deferred outflow of resources.

column3: Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments
column10: An acquisition of pension related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual pension plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132b

column3: Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Changes in Assumptions
column10: An acquisition of pension related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post?employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132a(2)

column3: Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience
column10: An acquisition of pension related net assets deferred due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 132a(1)

column3: Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pensions, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions

column17: Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P20; Paragraph: 154

column3: Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date
column10: An acquisition of pension related net assets due to contributions to the pension plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.

column10: Information about total amounts on the Capital Assets Footnote.
Used to represent information reported on the Capital Assets footnote.
Used as an identifier for Governmental activities or Business type activities. If Primary Governmental activities needs to be represented, do not use an axis.
Information about type of activities. Use for Governmental or Business activities. If Primary Government activities need to be represented, do not use an axis.

Primary government activities. A primary government is any state government or general purpose local government (municipality, village, township or county) as well as a special-purpose government (for example, a school district or a park district).
Governmental activities which are generally are financed through taxes, intergovernmental revenues, and other non-exchange revenues.

Represents business-type activities, which is one of two classes of activities reported in government-wide financial statements. Business-type activities are financed in whole or in part by fees charged to external parties for goods or services. These activities usually are reported in enterprise funds.
Used to collect information found on a Capital Assets footnote.

column10: Used to represent information reported on the Capital Assets footnote.
Used as an identifier for Governmental activities or Business type activities. If Primary Governmental activities needs to be represented, do not use an axis.
Information about type of activities. Use for Governmental or Business activities. If Primary Government activities need to be represented, do not use an axis.

Primary government activities. A primary government is any state government or general purpose local government (municipality, village, township or county) as well as a special-purpose government (for example, a school district or a park district).
Governmental activities which are generally are financed through taxes, intergovernmental revenues, and other non-exchange revenues.

Represents business-type activities, which is one of two classes of activities reported in government-wide financial statements. Business-type activities are financed in whole or in part by fees charged to external parties for goods or services. These activities usually are reported in enterprise funds.

Primary government activities. A primary government is any state government or general purpose local government (municipality, village, township or county) as well as a special-purpose government (for example, a school district or a park district).

Information about leases.

Amount of liabilities for short-term lease. GASB 87 indicates that a short-term lease is a lease that, at the commencement of the lease term, has a maximum possible term under the lease contract of 12 months (or less), including any options to extend, regardless of the probability of being exercised. For a lease that is cancelable by either the lessee or the lessor, such as a rolling month-to-month lease or a year-to-year lease, the maximum possible term is the non-cancelable period, including any notice periods. The lessor should recognize a liability if payments are received in advance. The lessee should recognize a liability for rent due if payments are to be made subsequent to the reporting period.

column10: Additions to net OPEB liability. An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.

Reductions from Net OPEB Liability. An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.

Used to collect information about the Long Term Debt footnote.
Used as an identifier for Governmental activities or Business type activities. If Primary Governmental activities needs to be represented, do not use an axis.
Information about type of activities. Use for Governmental or Business activities. If Primary Government activities need to be represented, do not use an axis.

Primary government activities. A primary government is any state government or general purpose local government (municipality, village, township or county) as well as a special-purpose government (for example, a school district or a park district).
Governmental activities which are generally are financed through taxes, intergovernmental revenues, and other non-exchange revenues.

Represents business-type activities, which is one of two classes of activities reported in government-wide financial statements. Business-type activities are financed in whole or in part by fees charged to external parties for goods or services. These activities usually are reported in enterprise funds.
Used as an identifier for the name of other long term debt.
Used to group information about items on the Long Term Debt footnote.

column3: Compensated Absences Payable, Noncurrent, at Beginning of Period

Compensated absences are compensated time off such as vacation and sick leave, which has been earned by employees and probable that the employer will compensate the employees through paid time off or some other means, such as cash payments at termination or retirement but not yet compensated by the employer.

column10: Information about Net OPEB liability.

column3: Net OPEB Liability at Beginning of Period
column10: The net OPEB liability is measured as the portion of the actuarial present value of projected benefit payments that is attributed to past periods of employee service, net of the OPEB plan's fiduciary net position.
column11: Net OPEB Liability at Beginning of Period
column12: Net OPEB Liability at End of Period
column14: LONG-TERM LIABILITIES, OPEB Obligation (Account No 335)
column17: [Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P50; Paragraph: 123], [Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P50; Paragraph: 152a]

column10: Additions to net OPEB liability. An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.

Reductions from Net OPEB Liability. An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.

column3: Net OPEB Liability at End of Period
column10: The net OPEB liability is measured as the portion of the actuarial present value of projected benefit payments that is attributed to past periods of employee service, net of the OPEB plan's fiduciary net position.
column11: Net OPEB Liability at Beginning of Period
column12: Net OPEB Liability at End of Period
column14: LONG-TERM LIABILITIES, OPEB Obligation (Account No 335)
column17: [Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P50; Paragraph: 123], [Publisher: GASB; Name: Codification; Section: P50; Paragraph: 152a]

column3: Net OPEB Liability, Principal Due Within One Year
column10: Net OPEB Liability, principal due within one year. An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.
